title: How to Add and Subtract Functions

methods.name: Adding or Subtracting Functions without an Input

steps.headline: Write out the functions that are being added or subtracted.
steps.description: Functions are usually stated as f(x) = relationship, where x is the variable input, and the relationship is stated as a formula for the variable x. Since you are adding or subtracting more than one function, they will be labeled differently, most likely f(x){\displaystyle f(x)} and g(x){\displaystyle g(x)}. For example, you might be asked to add the function f(x)=3x+2{\displaystyle f(x)=3x+2}, and the function g(x)=4−5x{\displaystyle g(x)=4-5x}. If you are being asked to add, you will often be asked to find (f+g)x{\displaystyle (f+g)x}. If you are being asked to subtract, you will often be asked to find (f−g)x{\displaystyle (f-g)x}.

steps.headline: Reorder the functions by degree of terms.
steps.description: This means ordering the formula by exponents, beginning with the largest exponent (x3,x2,x,{\displaystyle x^{3},x^{2},x,} etc.). If there is no exponent, order the first-degree term first (x), followed the constants (numbers without variables). For example, the function g(x){\displaystyle g(x)} would be reordered as −5x+4{\displaystyle -5x+4}. The f(x) function is already ordered by degree of terms.

steps.headline: Create an addition or subtraction problem using the two formulas.
steps.description: You can add/subtract horizontally or vertically, since you have ordered the functions by terms. For example, your function can be set up as (f+g)x=(3x+2)+(−5x+4){\displaystyle (f+g)x=(3x+2)+(-5x+4)}, or it could be set up vertically, with like terms lined up:+3x+2−5x+4{\displaystyle +{\begin{matrix}3x&+&2\\-5x&+&4\end{matrix}}}.

steps.headline: Add or subtract like terms.
steps.description: It is helpful to add/subtract in order of the degree of terms, beginning with the highest exponent (if any). For example, for (f+g)x=(3x+2)+(−5x+4){\displaystyle (f+g)x=(3x+2)+(-5x+4)}, you would first add the first-degree terms:3x+(−5x)=−2x{\displaystyle 3x+(-5x)=-2x}.Second, you would add the constants:2+4=6{\displaystyle 2+4=6}.So (f+g)x=−2x+6{\displaystyle (f+g)x=-2x+6}.

steps.headline: Follow the same process for adding or subtracting more than two functions.
steps.description: Adding or subtracting functions is always just a matter of adding/subtracting the like terms in the relationship formulas.

methods.name: Adding or Subtracting Functions with the Same Input

steps.headline: Add or subtract the functions, as described in Method 1.
steps.description: This will give you the formula relationship for your variable input (x). For example, you might find that (f+g)x=−2x+6{\displaystyle (f+g)x=-2x+6}.

steps.headline: Plug in the variable.
steps.description: Remember, this method only works if you are adding/subtracting functions with the same input variable. For example, you might be asked to find (f+g)(2){\displaystyle (f+g)(2)}. Your added function would then look like (f+g)(2)=−2(2)+6{\displaystyle (f+g)(2)=-2(2)+6}.

steps.headline: Complete the calculation.
steps.description: Remember to use the order of operations. For example:(f+g)(2)=−2(2)+6{\displaystyle (f+g)(2)=-2(2)+6}(f+g)(2)=−4+6{\displaystyle (f+g)(2)=-4+6}(f+g)(2)=2{\displaystyle (f+g)(2)=2}.

methods.name: Adding or Subtracting Functions with Different Inputs

steps.headline: Plug the appropriate variable into the first function and solve.
steps.description: Since you are working with two different variables (inputs), you cannot add the formulas and plug in one input, you have to complete one function at a time. For example, if you are given f(x)=3x+2{\displaystyle f(x)=3x+2} and g(x)=4−5x{\displaystyle g(x)=4-5x}, and are asked to find f(2)+g(3){\displaystyle f(2)+g(3)}, you would start by finding f(2){\displaystyle f(2)}. When you plug in the 2, you get:f(2)=3(2)+2{\displaystyle f(2)=3(2)+2}f(2)=6+2{\displaystyle f(2)=6+2}f(2)=8{\displaystyle f(2)=8}.

steps.headline: Plug the appropriate variable into the second function and solve.
steps.description: Make sure you are plugging in the correct variable to the correct function. For example, if g(x)=4−5x{\displaystyle g(x)=4-5x}, then: g(3)=4−5(3){\displaystyle g(3)=4-5(3)}g(3)=4−15{\displaystyle g(3)=4-15}g(3)=−11{\displaystyle g(3)=-11}

steps.headline: Add or subtract the two outputs.
steps.description: The result will be the sum or difference of the two functions, given the provided variables. For example, if f(2)=8{\displaystyle f(2)=8} and g(3)=−11{\displaystyle g(3)=-11}, then: f(2)+g(3)=8+(−11){\displaystyle f(2)+g(3)=8+(-11)}f(2)+g(3)=−3{\displaystyle f(2)+g(3)=-3}.
